custom_fields.key_topics: Patterns of innovation, technology lifecycle, , signals of change, innovation by identifying unsolved problems, disruptive versus sustaining innovation, design-driven innovation, open innovation, innovation in platform markets, complementary assets, sustainability and imitability, Business Model Canvas (BMC), Resources, Processes and Values (RPV) framework, Value Chain Evolution (VCE), Minimum Viable Product or Service (MVP/S), Market Entry Point (MEP), organizing for innovation, innovation financing strategies, monetizing innovation, marketing channel development.
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Students should have some prior exposure to concepts of Entrepreneurship
custom_fields.assessment_structure:
Students will be graded on:
Class participation (30%)
Case studies (25%)
Weekly final project deliverables* (25%)
Final Project and Presentation (20%)

*In developing the final project there will be weekly deliverables on elements of the final business plan such as the identification of the target market, development of the minimal entry product, identification of production and marketing channel partners, crafting the market entry strategy, and development of a financing strategy to initial profitability.
custom_fields.goals: Upon completion of this course students will be able to use a variety of frameworks for identifying ideas for innovative productsservices be able to analyze the competitive environment for a new product and the market potential of a new innovation andor business opportunity have developed a comprehensive solution to an identified real world problem have acquired experience utilizing lean start up techniques to develop a complete business plan for commercializing a new innovation be able to present the solution in a compelling manner.
custom_fields.relevance: For those interested in becoming entrepreneurs, or new product developers within a larger firm, this course will provide both a theoretical understanding of the innovation process and how successful innovation occurs, and a practical exposure to developing a plan for creating and introducing a new product in a startup organization.
custom_fields.learning_resources: There will be a packet of assigned readings and cases. Detailed lecture notes will be available during the semester.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: Doing assigned readings. Case writeups. Research to identify a new product concept. Weekly milestone reports for the final project, and final project presentation.

long_desc: The course is targeted at entrepreneurs and innovators who are interested in introducing innovations to the marketplace through startup, emerging and established organizations.  Class participants will learn how to evaluate, develop and implement opportunities for innovation, using an emergent or iterative approach the lean methodology. Students will also learn a variety of methodologies to identify opportunities for innovation including how to identify unserved customers, identifying what jobs customers need to do, and how to incorporate innovations originating from end users, suppliers, materials manufacturers, and other entities outside the firm.  Students will learn how to develop a Business Model, identify a Minimum Viable Product, and a Market Entry Point.    The course is divided into two parts.  In the first half students will be exposed to theories and strategies of innovation through readings and case studies.  In the second half students will identify and develop their own product concept utilizing concepts developed in the first part of the course, and stepbystep develop their business model, organizational plan, strategic partners, marketing message, sales plan, and financing strategy. This course may use thirdparty course material that is not available for individual purchase from the publisher.   If so, the thirdparty course material will be secured and provided by the Tepper School to students enrolled in the course, and students enrolled in the course will be required to pay to the University the associated additional course materials fee for the thirdparty course material provided.   The amount of the course materials fee is dependent on the Universitys cost of the particular materials provided, and typically ranges from 13 to 75.

prereqs.text: ((73-102 at least D) or (73-100 at least D)) and ((70-414 at least D) or (70-425 at least D) or (70-415 at least D) or (15-390 at least D) or (70-420 at least D) or (70-421 at least D))

name: Commercialization and Innovation
